A 25-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent episodes of bloody urine and hearing loss. On physical examination, he has mild edema in the lower extremities. Family history reveals that his maternal uncle and grandfather had similar kidney problems and hearing impairment. Laboratory investigations show elevated proteinuria and microscopic hematuria. A renal biopsy is performed, which reveals thinning and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B) Alport S

Topic Description
Definition A genetic disorder characterized by abnormalities in type IV collagen, leading to kidney, ear, and eye problems.
Types of Inheritance - X-linked Alport Syndrome: Most common and severe form, passed from mothers (carriers) to sons (usually affected) or daughters (usually carriers).
  - Autosomal Recessive Alport Syndrome: Both parents are carriers, and the condition affects both males and females equally.
  - Autosomal Dominant Alport Syndrome: Inherited from one affected parent, and both males and females can be affected.
Clinical Features - Hematuria (blood in urine) visible under a microscope.
  - Proteinuria (excess protein in urine).
  - Progressive renal impairment leading to chronic kidney disease (CKD) and end-stage renal failure (ESRD).
  - Sensorineural hearing loss, usually affecting high-frequency sounds.
  - Ocular abnormalities like anterior lenticonus and cataracts (less common).
Renal Biopsy Findings - "Basket-weave" appearance of the glomerular basement membrane on electron microscopy.
  - Thinning and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane.
  - Irregular thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (X-linked Alport Syndrome).
Genetics Mutations in the COL4A3, COL4A4, or COL4A5 genes that encode type IV collagen proteins.
Diagnosis - Urinalysis showing hematuria and proteinuria.
  - Genetic testing to identify mutations in COL4A3, COL4A4, or COL4A5 genes.
  - Renal biopsy to confirm characteristic glomerular basement membrane changes.
Management - Supportive care for kidney problems, including blood pressure control and management of proteinuria.
  - Hearing aids for hearing loss.
  - Regular eye examinations for ocular complications.
  - Kidney transplantation for end-stage renal failure.
Prognosis - Variable based on the type of Alport Syndrome and the severity of kidney involvement.
  - X-linked Alport Syndrome typically has the poorest prognosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman receives neuraxial opioids for postoperative analgesia. What is the most common side effect she is most likely to experience with this intervention?

A 5-year-old boy child is being operated on for circumcision under general anaesthesia with caudal analgesic supplements. His past medical history is unremarkable. He is up to date with his current vaccination. On examination, his blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, his pulse is 110/min, and his respiratory rate is 18/min. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. A respiratory examination reveals normal breathing with equal air entry bilaterally. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. Neurological examination is unremarkable. The chest x-ray is normal. Intravenous induction with propofol has been planned. Which of the followings is an advantage of propofol over sevoflurane inhalation in this child?

options.label: A
options.text: Does not cause pain over injecting site

options.label: B
options.text: Blood pressure and cardiac output are better maintained

options.label: C
options.text: Propofol has a slower onset of action

options.label: D
options.text: Propofol has a quicke r onset of action

questions.correct_answer: D. Propofol has a quicke r onset of action
questions.explanation:
Intravenous anaesthetic agents, e.g. propofol Inhalational anaesthetic agents, e.g. sevoflurane
  1. Intravenous induction is faster, smoother and has a rapid recovery
  2. No specialised equipment is required
  3. Extensively used in outpatients
  4. Can be used as a sole anaesthetic agent in short surgical procedures
  5. Lesser perioperative respiratory complications compared to inhaled agents
  1. Inhalational induction is done in paediatric patients who are not cooperating and if there is no intravenous line to give an intravenous induction agent
  2. Special equipment is required to deliver and monitor the inspired concentration of the inhalational agents. Scavenging systems are required for the disposal of exhaled gases
  3. Slower onset of action and slower recovery than intravenous anaesthetic agents
  4. Less use in outpatients
  5. Cannot be used as a sole anaesthetic agent

1) Subxiphoid To look for pericardial fluid & 4 chamber view of the heart

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the OPD with complaints of persistent nasal discharge. A week ago, he had a low-grade fever, cough, headache, and watery nasal discharge. However, all the symptoms resolved after 3 days except the nasal discharge. On anterior and posterior rhinoscopy, a trilobed mass is seen, and a diagnosis of antrochoanal polyp is made. options.text: It is also known as Killian's polyp

options.label: B
options.text: It is seen in elderly patients

options.label: D
options.text: It grows in the nasal cavity towards the anterior choana

questions.correct_answer: A. It is also known as Killian's polyp
questions.explanation:
Antrochoanal polyp Ethmoidal polyp
Age Common in children Common in adult
Number Solitary Multiple
Laterality Unilateral Bilateral
Origin Maxillary sinus near the ostium Ethmoidal sinuses, middle turbinate and middle meatus
Growth Grows backwards to the choana; may hang down behind the soft palate Mostly grow anteriorly and may present at the nares
Size and shape Trilobed (dumb-bell)with antral, nasal and choanal parts. Choanal parts may protrude through the choana & fill the nasopharynx obstructing both sides Usually small and grape-like masses
Recurrence Uncommon if removed completely Common
Treatment The treatment is only surgical About 50% of patients respond to steroid therapy

Differences between Antrochoanal And Ethmoidal Polyps
  Antrochoanal Polyps Ethmoidal Polyps
 Age Common in children, it can occur in adults common in adults
 Aetiology Infection Allergy or Multifactorial
 Number Solitary Multiple
 Laterality Unilateral Bilateral
 Origin Maxillary sinus near the ostium Ethmoidal sinuses, uncinate process, middle turbinate, and middle meatus
Size and shape Trilobed with antral, nasal, and choanal parts. The choanal part may protrude through the choana and fill the nasopharynx, obstructing both sides. Usually, they are small and grape-like masses.
 Recurrence Uncommon, if removed completely Common
 Treatment Endoscopic sinus surgery Endoscopic sinus surgery

Pulmonary examination shows diffuse crackles and rhonchi. An X-ray of the chest shows a left upper lobe infiltrate of the lung. Concerning immunity, after a couple of weeks, a specific response from the adaptive immune system will appear in the patient's body. This high specificity or affinity maturation of T cells is due to the following:

In most prokaryotic cells, glycocalyx forms a protective layer external to the cell wall called the capsule. A capsule is a negatively charged and smooth structure of a prokaryotic cell that prevents the adhesion of phagocytes and the engulfment of invading bacteria by the cells of the host immune system. Which of the following microorganisms lack this protective mechanism?

A 62-year-old male patient presents signs and symptoms suggestive of meningitis which has been resistant to antibiotics for his current illness for the last 02 weeks. His MRI brain is revealing ventriculomegaly and a brain abscess. Importantly, he has a pathognomic feature of fungal infection. Later he is suspected of having a fungal disease. His sample was sent for staining and further processing to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following is a correctly matched stain in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Stain

Comments

 

Mycology Lab

Calcofluor white

fluorochrome that binds glucans and chit in fungal cell wall;

Lactophenol Cotton Blue

cotton blue (aka analine blue) dye stains chitin and allows visualization of fungal elements following scraping or tape preparation from culture

 

Pathology

Hematoxylin and esoin (H&E)

used to visualize host cell response to fungi but doesn't stain most fungi: exceptions are Aspergillus spp. and the Mucorales.

Grocott methenamine silver (GMS)

stains fungal cell wall black

Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)

stains polysaccharide component of fungal cell wall magenta

 

Selected specific stains

India ink

"negative" stain that outlines the polysaccharide capsule of Cryptococcus sp: not as sensitive as Ag detection for cryptococcal meningitis: some strains are reportedly acapsular.

Mucicarmine

can be used to stain mucopolysaccharide capsule of Cryptococcus sp.: also stains Blastornyces and Rhinospondiurn

Fontana-Masson

silver stain used to detect melanin pigment in cell walls of Cyptococcus

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman attended the outpatient department with a lump measuring 5x4cm in the upper outer quadrant of her right breast. questions.text: A 56-year-old female presents to the clinic with a palpable lump in the breast . After the triple assessment, the diagnosis has been labelled as locally advanced breast cancer . Which of the following does not classify as locally advanced breast cancer?
questions.explanation:
Stage Description Treatment
Stage 0 (DCIS) Ductal Carcinoma In Situ - Non-invasive cancer that is confined to the ducts and has not spread to surrounding tissues. - Lumpectomy or mastectomy with or without radiation therapy.
    - Hormone therapy (if hormone receptor-positive).
Stage I Tumor size is up to 2 cm, and cancer has not spread to lymph nodes or distant organs. - Lumpectomy or mastectomy with or without radiation therapy.
    - Sentinel lymph node biopsy (for lymph node assessment).
    - Chemotherapy (for high-risk cases or aggressive tumors).
    - Hormone therapy (if hormone receptor-positive).
Stage II Tumor size is 2-5 cm, or cancer has spread to a few nearby lymph nodes, but not to distant organs. - Lumpectomy or mastectomy with or without radiation therapy.
    - Axillary lymph node dissection (for lymph node assessment).
    - Chemotherapy (based on tumor characteristics and lymph node status).
    - Hormone therapy (if hormone receptor-positive).
Stage III Tumor size is larger than 5 cm, or cancer has extensively spread to nearby lymph nodes, but not to distant organs. - Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (prior to surgery) to shrink the tumor.
    - Mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection.
    - Post-mastectomy radiation therapy (if indicated).
    - Adjuvant chemotherapy (after surgery) and/or hormone therapy.
Stage IV Cancer has spread to distant organs, such as the lungs, liver, bones, or brain. - Palliative treatments, including targeted therapy, immunotherapy, or chemotherapy, to manage symptoms and improve quality of life.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male chronic smoker presented with a swelling on the right side of the face for the past one and a half years. The onset was insidious, and the swelling gradually increased in size. The skin over the swelling is normal. Examination showed a firm right preauricular mass. A mass biopsy showed numerous papillations covered by monomorphic oncotic cells and germinal centers. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

On examination of the posterior triangle of the neck , a soft, compressible, and painless swelling that trans-illuminates is found . A 60-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of nausea, vomiting, and headache after a head injury due to accidental trauma caused by a hammer on his head while working. On examination, there are forehead, nasal bridge, and upper lip injuries. However, his eye movements and vision are normal bilaterally. His computed tomography (CT) scan of the facial bones shows Le fort II fracture. What are the most likely structures in this patient that have been damaged?

options.label: A
options.text: Fracture Line Runs Above and Parallel to the Palate

options.label: B
options.text: Fracture Line Runs High Through the Nasal Bridge, Septum, And Ethmoids

options.label: C
options.text: Root of Nose, Lacrimal Bone , Orbital Floor, And Pterygoid Plate

options.label: D
options.text: Complete Disjunction of The Facial Skeleton from The Skull Base

questions.correct_answer: C. Root of Nose, Lacrimal Bone , Orbital Floor, And Pterygoid Plate
questions.explanation:
Le fort I
  • Fracture line runs above and parallel to palate
  • Effectively separates alveolus and palate from the facial skeleton above
Le fort II
  • Pyramidal in shape
  • Passes through the root of nose, lacrimal bone, floor of orbit, upper part of maxillary sinus, and pterygoid plate
  • Orbital floor is always involved
Le fort III
  • Complete disjunction of the facial skeleton from the skull base
  • Fracture line runs high through the nasal bridge, septum, and ethmoids and through the bones of orbit to the frontozygomatic suture

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with occasional severe headaches, nausea, and vomiting . On his examination, b lood pressure while sitting is 230/130 mmHg with a heart rate of 90 beats/min, but on standing , the blood pressure drops to 200/100 mmHg and the heart rate increases to 140 beats/min. A cardiovascular examination depicted tachycardia with normal S1 and S2 sounds. The patient's lungs are clear. The optic discs are blurred, but there are no exudates or haemorrhages . She also gives a history of weight gain of around 5 kg in the last 3 months despite regular diet and physical activity. Her thyroid profile show TSH- 20 mU/L & free T4 is low. After 8 days of birth, a woman comes to the clinic complaining of no milk flow started yet, fatigue, craving for salt and sugars. Her vitals are deranged with low blood pressure and pulse. She is diagnosed with Sheehan syndrome. Which is the first drug to be started in Sheehan's syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Definition Sheehan Syndrome, also known as postpartum hypopituitarism, is a rare medical condition that occurs due to severe blood loss during childbirth, leading to damage or necrosis of the pituitary gland. This damage results in a deficiency of one or more pituitary hormones.
Etiology Primary cause is postpartum hemorrhage, which reduces blood supply to the pituitary gland, leading to tissue damage.
Clinical Features - Failure to lactate (breast milk production) after childbirth. - Absence of menstruation (amenorrhea) or irregular menstrual cycles. - Fatigue and weakness. - Weight loss. - Hypothyroidism-like symptoms (cold intolerance, constipation, dry skin). - Low blood pressure. - Loss of pubic and axillary hair. - Decreased libido and sexual dysfunction. - Depression and mood changes.
Diagnosis 1. Clinical evaluation based on symptoms and medical history. 2. Hormonal blood tests to assess deficiencies in pituitary hormones, including cortisol, thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and prolactin. 3. Brain imaging (MRI) to visualize the pituitary gland.
Treatment Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) is the primary treatment, which involves replacing the deficient hormones. This may include cortisol (glucocorticoids), thyroid hormones, estrogen, and/or progesterone.
Prognosis With proper diagnosis and hormone replacement therapy, most symptoms can be effectively managed, and individuals with Sheehan Syndrome can lead normal lives.
Complications Untreated or inadequately managed Sheehan Syndrome can lead to adrenal crisis, hypothyroidism, osteoporosis, and other complications.
Prevention Early recognition and management of postpartum hemorrhage can help prevent Sheehan Syndrome.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency department immediately after an accident. . The patient is actively bleeding in multiple sites of the body. Primary interventions have not stopped the bleeding, and vitals are deteriorating. The physician has decided to give FFP's, but there is no time for cross-matching. Which of the following group's FFP's can be transfused safely?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Fresh frozen plasma contains the labile clotting factors and plasma proteins.
  • ↳ After separation and freezing plasma at -30°C from a donor unit of blood, FFP is collected.
  • ↳ FFP should be used within six hours after thawing, ideally within two hours , to prevent deterioration of clotting factors.
  • ↳ FFP does not need to be cross-matched but should be ABO compatible .
  • ↳ The first preference of FFP is that of the same ABO group as the patient.
  • ↳ In an emergency, FFP of a different ABO group is preferable if it has no significant anti-A or anti-B antibodies .
  • ↳ FFP from the AB group no anti-A or anti-B antibodies and is usually preferred if blood grouping is not possible.
  • ↳ FFP doesn't need RhD compatibility as it is unlikely to cause RhD sensitization.
  • ↳ Universal Blood donor O negative Universal Blood Acceptor AB positive Universal FFP donor AB positive Universal FFP acceptor O negative
  • ↳ Universal Blood donor O negative
  • ↳ Universal Blood donor
  • ↳ Universal Blood donor
  • ↳ O negative
  • ↳ O negative
  • ↳ Universal Blood Acceptor AB positive
  • ↳ Universal Blood Acceptor
  • ↳ Universal Blood Acceptor
  • ↳ AB positive
  • ↳ AB positive
  • ↳ Universal FFP donor AB positive
  • ↳ Universal FFP donor
  • ↳ AB positive
  • ↳ Universal FFP acceptor O negative
  • ↳ Universal FFP acceptor
  • ↳ Universal FFP acceptor
  • ↳ O negative
  • ↳ O negative
  • ↳ Option A: O –
  • ↳ O – blood group has anti-A and anti-B antibodies but no antigens in the plasma. As it has significant anti-A or anti-B antibodies, it can't be used as a universal FFP donor.
  • ↳ O – blood group has anti-A and anti-B antibodies but no antigens in the plasma.
  • ↳ As it has significant anti-A or anti-B antibodies, it can't be used as a universal FFP donor.
  • ↳ Option B: O +
  • ↳ O+ blood has no A or B antigens, and Rh antigen is present. It has anti-A and anti-B antibodies , so it can't be transfused as a universal FFP donor.
  • ↳ O+ blood has no A or B antigens, and Rh antigen is present.
  • ↳ It has anti-A and anti-B antibodies , so it can't be transfused as a universal FFP donor.
  • ↳ Option C: A +
  • ↳ A+ blood has both A and Rh antigens . It also has an anti-B antibody . The presence of any antibody in a blood group is a contraindication for being a universal donor.
  • ↳ A+ blood has both A and Rh antigens . It also has an anti-B antibody .
  • ↳ The presence of any antibody in a blood group is a contraindication for being a universal donor.

A 27-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of fertility. She has been unable to conceive for 2 years despite regular intercourse with her husband twice weekly. Menarche occurs at the age of 12 years, and menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 4 to 5 days. She is undergoing evaluation for infertility. She is being monitored for ovulation with serial ultrasounds and LH levels. Ovulation in this patient is expected to occur how many hours after an LH surge is demonstrated?
questions.explanation:
Menstrual Cycle Phase Duration Hormonal Changes Events
Menstrual Phase 3-7 days Low estrogen and progesterone Shedding of the endometrial lining; menstrual bleeding occurs
Follicular Phase 7-21 days Increasing estrogen levels Follicles in the ovaries mature, preparing to release an egg
    Low progesterone levels Uterine lining begins to thicken
Ovulation 1-2 days Surge in luteinizing hormone (LH) and estrogen Release of a mature egg (ovum) from the ovary
Luteal Phase 10-16 days Increased progesterone levels The uterine lining continues to thicken, preparing for potential embryo implantation
    Elevated estrogen levels If pregnancy does not occur, hormones begin to decline
Premenstrual Phase 2-10 days Declining estrogen and progesterone PMS symptoms may occur, and the endometrial lining is shed if fertilization did not happen

questions.text: Emergency thoracotomy can be defined as thoracotomy "occurring either immediately at the site of injury, or in the emergency department or operating room as an integral part of the initial resuscitation process". Following emergency thoracotomy, the overall survival rates for penetrating thoracic trauma are around 9-12% but have been reported to be as high as 38%.Emergency thoracotomy is indicated following chest trauma in the following conditions except:-
questions.explanation:
Indications of Thoracotomy
  • Initial tube thoracostomy drainage of > 1000 ml (penetrating injury) or >1500 ml (blunt injury)
  • Ongoing tube thoracostomy drainage of >200 ml/hr for 3 consecutive hours in non-caogulopathic patients
  • Caked hemothorax despite of placement of two chest tubes Tracheo-bronchial injury
  • Selected descending torn aorta or great vessel injury
  • Pericardial tamponade
  • Cardiac herniation
  • Massive air leak from chest tube with inadequate ventilation
  • Open pneumothorax Esophageal perforation

questions.text: A community medicine intern was asked to compare two study designs. What is the similarity between Cross-sectional study design and Ecological study design?

options.label: A
options.text: Both studies are done at a point of time

options.label: C
options.text: Both are based on primary data

options.label: D
options.text: The unit of study is the population

questions.correct_answer: A. Both studies are done at a point of time
questions.explanation:
Cross-Sectional Study Ecological Study
Both studies are done at a point of time
  • This study is based on primary data i.e. collected by the Investigator himself from House to House.
  • It provides “Prevalence”, so Also known as Prevalence Study
  • It is also known as the “SNAPSHOT Study”.
  • This study is based on Secondary Data i.e. Collected data from the records of the hospital. Data is not collected by Investigator himself.
  • It is used in Nutritional Surveys
  • The strength of association/prevalence cannot be calculated.
  • The unit of study is population and results are extrapolated and projected not on Individuals but on the total population.
  • This drawback is known as the “Ecological Fallacy”.
